title: Day 13 - Create a Side Hustle Shopping List
mainPromise: You will create a lean shopping list that covers only what you need to sell and deliver, with costs, alternatives, and a setup order.

teachings.title: Tools should earn their place
teachings.content:
Tools feel productive because they are tangible. But tools also create overhead: logins, learning curves, subscriptions, and distractions.

A lean side hustle uses as few tools as possible. Your goal is not to build a perfect stack. Your goal is to deliver the promise and get paid.

A good rule is: if a tool does not reduce buyer risk, reduce delivery time, or reduce mistakes, it is optional for now.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not choose tools intentionally, you will waste money and time before you sell.

teachings.title: Shopping lists need costs and exits
teachings.content:
A shopping list is incomplete without cost and exit. Cost is the monthly or per-use amount. Exit is how you cancel, downgrade, or stop using it if it is not needed.

Also consider substitutes. Many paid tools can be replaced by a document template, a spreadsheet, or a free tier. You are not avoiding quality. You are avoiding complexity before revenue.

Today you will build a shopping list that includes cost, alternative, and exit plan.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not include exits, small subscriptions become permanent leaks.

teachings.title: Setup order matters
teachings.content:
Even a lean stack becomes confusing if you set it up randomly. You need an order that matches your workflow: payment first, intake second, delivery templates third, tracking last.

You will define the smallest setup sequence that gets you to ready to sell. This prevents tool setup from becoming a never-ending project.

A good setup plan also includes a time cap for each step. That keeps you moving.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not define a setup order, you will bounce between tools and finish none.

doBlocks.title: Define your tool requirements
steps: List the tasks your service requires from lead to delivery.
For each task, write the minimum tool capability needed.
Mark what you already have vs what you must add.

items.label: Listed 8 to 12 tasks in your service lifecycle
items.evidencePrompt: List 8 to 12 tasks from lead to delivery.

items.label: Wrote the minimum tool requirement per task
items.evidencePrompt: Provide task-to-requirement mapping (one line per task).

items.label: Marked each requirement as Have, Use Free, or Need Paid
items.evidencePrompt: Add labels to each task requirement: Have, Use Free, Need Paid.

items.label: Wrote one rule for no new tools unless
items.evidencePrompt: Write one sentence that limits new tools.

doBlocks.example: Task: Collect intake -> Requirement: simple form + export responses. Label: Use Free. Rule: No new tools unless it removes a known bottleneck in delivery.

doBlocks.title: Build the lean shopping list
steps: List each tool you plan to use (including free tools).
For each, record cost, purpose, and free alternative.
Add a cancellation note and a review date.

items.label: Listed 6 to 12 tools or resources you will use
items.evidencePrompt: List 6 to 12 tools/resources you plan to use.

items.label: Recorded cost and billing frequency for each
items.evidencePrompt: Provide cost and billing frequency per tool.

items.label: Listed a free alternative or downgrade for each
items.evidencePrompt: Provide an alternative or downgrade option for each tool.

items.label: Added a cancellation note and review date for each paid tool
items.evidencePrompt: For paid tools, write cancellation notes and a review date.

doBlocks.example: Tool: Payment processor cost: 2.9% + fee alternative: invoice + bank transfer exit: keep account, stop links. Tool: Form tool cost: free alternative: email intake template.

doBlocks.title: Write your setup sequence
steps: Choose the 5 to 7 setup steps that create a working system.
Assign a time cap to each step.
Define the ready to sell condition.

items.label: Wrote a 5 to 7 step setup sequence
Assigned a time cap to each step
items.evidencePrompt: Add minutes to each setup step.

items.label: Defined the ready-to-sell condition in one sentence
items.evidencePrompt: Write one sentence that defines ready-to-sell.

items.label: Chose one tool you will postpone and why
items.evidencePrompt: Write one line naming the postponed tool and your reason.

doBlocks.example: Ready-to-sell: I have a payment link, an intake form, and a handoff template ready. Postpone: Website builder postponed until after first paid delivery.

outputs: Task-to-tool requirements map with Have/Free/Paid labels
Lean shopping list with costs, alternatives, and exit notes
Ready-to-sell condition and one postponed tool decision
wrap.tomorrowPreview: Tomorrow you will set up a clean way to get paid, including a payment link, a basic receipt description, and a test transaction flow.
